metadata.case_name: Commissioner of Income-tax, Madhya Pradesh and Bhopal v. Vyas Dotiwala

facts.text: In or about July 1943, Deputy Commissioner, Amraoti, evolved a scheme for distribution of standard cloth due to cloth shortage.

Kisanlal Vyas and firm Edulji Framji Dotiwala (assessees, association of persons referred to as Vyas Dotiwala) undertook to finance the scheme without charging interest or profit and were appointed financiers and distributors for Amraoti town, camp and interior areas.
Assessees agreed to open account in Imperial Bank of India to finance cloth purchases; orders placed by Government with mills.
On arrival of consignment, assessees to pay Deputy Commissioner value of consignment plus 6-1/4% of ex-mill price; consignment checked and delivered to assessees on receipt.
Deputy Commissioner to pay assessees 4-1/2% of ex-mill price for contingent expenses (not to exceed 3%).

Cloth distributed by assessees through shop in Amraoti and through Tehsildars with Patils in interiors; distribution under control of Deputy Commissioner who decided sale price and entitled buyers, responsible for sale proceeds from Tehsildars.
Out of sale proceeds, Deputy Commissioner to pay assessees advances made for cloth.

Para 14 of scheme: 'Profits resulting from the scheme shall be utilised for such charitable purposes as may be decided on by the Deputy Commissioner in consultation with the advisory committee appointed to supervise the scheme.'
Books of assessees showed profits of Rs. 34,737/- for assessment year 1945-46 and Rs. 17,682/- for 1946-47 from working the scheme.
Income-tax Officer assessed assessees on these profits; assessees contended income not theirs and exempt under s.4(3)(i-a) of Indian Income-tax Act, 1922.
Appellate Assistant Commissioner confirmed ITO's order.

Appellate Tribunal held profits not income of assessees as scheme was of Deputy Commissioner under his control, assessees merely financiers/managers; set aside assessments. Assessees had raised two grounds per letter dated January 22, 1947.

On revenue application, Tribunal referred question under s.66(1): 'Whether on the facts of this case any income accrued to Messrs. Vyas and Dotiwala as the result of their associating themselves as financiers in the scheme for the distribution of standard cloth and, if so whether such income was assessable in their hands.'
Nagpur High Court answered question in negative: no actual or deemed receipt under s.4.
Appeal by special leave to Supreme Court by Commissioner; respondents did not appear.
Assessees not made to pay out profits for charity.

legal_issues.text: Whether on the facts of this case any income accrued to Messrs. Vyas and Dotiwala as the result of their associating themselves as financiers in the scheme for the distribution of standard cloth and, if so whether such income was assessable in their hands.
Whether profits exempt under s.4(3)(i-a) of Indian Income-tax Act, 1922.

petitioner_arguments.text: High Court failed to appreciate real question: not whether income received or deemed received, but whether income accrued and profits formed income of assessees.
Tribunal wrong: assessees worked scheme producing profits; control by Deputy Commissioner does not prevent it being business by assessees; they agreed to do business in certain manner.
Deputy Commissioner guaranteed Tehsildars' payments, treating assessees as owners; assessees' alternative claim for exemption under s.4(3)(i-a) implies they carried on business.

Para 14 contemplates profits resulting from scheme belonging to assessees, to be devoted to charity; without it, profits utilisable by assessees; agreeing to charity does not change character as their income.
Assessees undertook to finance without interest/profit but actually made profits, liable to tax thereon.

court_reasoning.text: Agree with Solicitor-General: High Court erred by focusing on receipt/deemed receipt under s.4 instead of accrual and whether profits income of assessees.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Real question is accrual of income, not receipt.

court_reasoning.text: Tribunal wrong: assessees worked scheme producing profits; control by Deputy Commissioner does not prevent business by assessees; they agreed to business in certain manner.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Control does not negate business carried on by assessees.

court_reasoning.text: DC guarantee of Tehsildars' payments indicates assessees owners; loss otherwise on assessees; exemption claim implies business.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Assessees treated as owners of business.

court_reasoning.text: Para 14 shows profits belonged to assessees, hence need to devote to charity; if Government's, no need for provision.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Profits undoubtedly belonged to assessees apart from para 14.

court_reasoning.text: Agreement to devote to charity does not change profits' character as assessees' income; liable to tax even if agreed not to make profits, as they did.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Profits made by assessees are their income.

court_reasoning.text: No exemption under s.4(3)(i-a): scheme not carried on behalf of religious/charitable institution.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Scheme not on behalf of any institution.

holdings.text: Profits were income which accrued to assessees from working the scheme and such income is assessable to income-tax.

statutes_cited.name: Indian Income-tax Act, 1922
statutes_cited.relevance: Charging section s.4 for accrual of income; exemption under s.4(3)(i-a) rejected; reference under s.66(1).

outcome.summary: Supreme Court answered the referred question in the affirmative, holding that profits accrued as income to the assessees and were assessable to income-tax, not exempt under s.4(3)(i-a); reversed High Court.
outcome.relief_granted: Revenue's position upheld; assessments revived implicitly.

key_quotes.text: "Profits resulting from the scheme shall be utilised for such charitable purposes as may be decided on by the Deputy Commissioner in consultation with the advisory committee appointed to supervise the scheme."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Para 14 of scheme, key to determining ownership of profits.

key_quotes.text: The fact remains that the working of the scheme produced profits and apart from para. 14 such profits undoubtedly belonged to the assessees.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core finding on accrual of income to assessees.

key_quotes.text: If they chose to agree by para. 14 to devote the profits to charity, that was their business the profits made by them would not change their character and cease to be the assessees income because they agreed to devote their income to charity.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Rejects argument that charity dedication exempts from tax.
